options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Insight into the history and functioning of central banks across the world
Learnt a great deal about central banking and financial stability legislation and approaches to it around the world.
A full understanding of central banking, including history, purposes, and controversies.
Knowledge of central banks policies across the globe

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The case studies and papers are fantastic. Lectures were mostly from the slides and it would be great if professor English could depart from them at some points.
Great structure to the course and the teaching was brilliant. I do think it could have been improved a bit with a more streamlined selection of readings.

Strengths: Course materials/lectures, professor, policy papers, guest speakers, cases (reading the case materials and writing the policy recommendations)
Weaknesses: Reading structure (discussing the mandatory papers in class), in-class case discussions

Recommendations: Change the structure of the readings so that the papers we discuss in class are "optional" (I found reading them to be relatively unrewarding, as we discussed them extensively in class) and the ones we don't discuss are "mandatory". Likewise, consider removing the in-class discussion of case materials (which felt repetitive) and replacing it with an alternative (e.g., a one page response to someone else's policy recommendation).
Make it more interactive for Yale college students. It is pretty intimidating for us to share our opinions when most of the other students are graduates who have worked for central banks.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The tabletop and case studies worked well but sometimes I only spoke at the end when all was said.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. It's a very informative class and a nice overview of Central Banking.
I would most definitely recommend the course. Prof. English is a great instructor, and the class is very engaging.

I would absolutely recommend this course to certain students. If you have a bit of time to spend on the course and are genuinely interested in central banking, absolutely take this. If you aren't interested in central banking or have a very busy schedule, read the syllabus, go to the first class, and make a careful decision. I loved this course, but I could see how someone would not.
